translated: The Buddha Speaks the Sutra of the Dharma King
In that light, the Bodhisattva...
... immediately rose from his seat, circumambulated the Buddha three times, and then stood to one side.
He prostrated himself on the ground, wept sorrowfully, and said to the Buddha:
Honored One among the Gods!
The Tathagata is about to enter nirvana, and the time has come.

After your parinirvana, for 1,500 years, the beings in the five turbidities will often commit evil deeds, exclusively engaging in the ten evil ways. Such beings will have little merit and virtue, and will find it difficult to understand the profound and wondrous Dharma of the twelve divisions of the canon spoken by the Buddha, with its extensive meaning and difficult to grasp.

I pray that the Buddha, out of compassion, will speak the definitive truth of the Mahayana, enabling these beings to obtain the true wondrous medicine to cure all poisonous illnesses and bring about complete healing.
The Buddha said to Bodhisattva Akasagarbha:ğŸ”½Excellent, excellent!
Excellent, excellent!ğŸ”½
Good men!
You are able to ask about such matters for the sake of all beings, and will attain great benefits beyond conception.
I will explain for you the true great vehicle, the definitive ultimate meaning.
Why is this?

In order to deliver beings, to enable all beings to be free from afflictions, to leave the suffering of hell and be reborn in the pure lands, to definitely attain liberation and transcend birth and death.
You should all be single-minded, and I will explain for you.
At that time, the great assembly all greatly rejoiced and leaped for joy, speaking with different mouths but the same voice, and all said:
May the Buddha have compassion and explain for us.
The Buddha said:
All good men!

If you wish to seek liberation, you should sever clinging, be single-minded and not two, abandon the characteristics of the mind of existence, and the nature of the mind is empty. Within the nature of the mind, there is no defilement and no abandonment.
If there is no grasping or abandoning, then there is nothing to attain;
If there is nothing to be attained, that is called bodhi.
Why is it so?
Many afflictions all arise from a single mind. If the mind does not arise, afflictions do not arise. In the cognition of various objects, there is then no grasping or rejecting.
If there is no grasping or rejecting, then one is free from all attachments;
if one is free from all attachments, then one does not grasp at objects.
Bodhisattva Ä€kÄÅ›agarbha addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
The cognition of sentient beings' objects can give rise to good and evil.
This is the place of dependent arising, where internal and external phenomena mutually enter each other.
How can one not grasp or reject within this?
The Buddha told Bodhisattva Ä€kÄÅ›agarbha:
Good man!
In the contemplation of a single meditative absorption, all internal and external are ultimately non-existent.
Why is it so?
Contemplating internally, the true nature of the internal does not arise. Contemplating externally, external ignorance does not arise.
Non-arising and non-occurrence are precisely non-nirvana, which is purity, the wondrous excellent medicine.
Bodhisattva Akasagarbha addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

The TathÄgata's teachings on the profound and subtle true characteristics of the MahÄyÄna, the unsurpassed good medicine for entering the truth of the One Vehicle, are difficult for sentient beings with impure three karmas, who commit the ten evil deeds and engage in the conduct of icchantikas, with their narrow and inferior faculties, to comprehend. How can we use skillful means to make them enter the MahÄyÄna?
The Buddha told Bodhisattva Akasagarbha:
I have skillful means to make them enter the MahÄyÄna.
Bodhisattva Akasagarbha addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

In the past, I heard the TathÄgata teach the six perfections for those of the MahÄyÄna, the twelve links of dependent arising for those of the middle vehicle, the four truths for those of the HÄ«nayÄna, and the ten wholesome deeds for icchantikas, all in accordance with their diseased faculties and prescribing good medicine.
How can the teaching of the One Vehicle today save these four types of people?
The Buddha told Bodhisattva Akasagarbha:

I speak of the One Vehicle Dharma, which is like the earth that can give birth to myriad things and nurture all, like the great rain that universally moistens all, and the things that grow in the earth all receive nourishment;

It is like a single grain of rice or a single flavor of food, which all sentient beings in the world, whether human or non-human, take as sustenance, and those who eat it are all able to nourish their bodies and lives.

It is like the Medicine King skillfully compounding wonderful elixirs, which cure the heat illnesses of the multitude, bringing coolness, and cure the cold illnesses of the multitude, bringing warmth, and stop diarrhea when taken, and relieve constipation when taken, and no illness is not cured.
The way I speak of the One Vehicle Dharma to those four kinds of people and cure their illnesses is also like this.
Bodhisattva Akasagarbha addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
By what skillful means can those sentient beings who commit the ten evil deeds and are icchantikas enter the One Vehicle path?
The Buddha told Bodhisattva Akasagarbha:
Good man!
My teaching of the One Vehicle is itself endowed with the Three Vehicles. There is no separate teaching of the Three Vehicles.
You should listen attentively, and I will proclaim it for you.
Good sons!

The wondrous Way deeply embodies the one characteristic, which is non-dual. It is due to skillful means that the Three Vehicles are spoken of. All dharmas and the Three Vehicles are in accord with the one contemplation. Although all sentient beings have four kinds, their Buddha-nature is also non-dual.
Why is this?
All Buddhas and all sentient beings have the same nature and characteristics, the same essence without difference. Sentient beings themselves give rise to discrimination.

The Buddha is sentient beings, and sentient beings are the Buddha. All sentient beings have Buddha-nature. The Buddha-nature and the sentient being-nature are both the same nature. Because the one nature is the same in all dharmas, I have skillful means to cause entry into the One Vehicle.
Good sons!

Cause those sentient beings to firmly establish the city of mind, not allowing the thief to enter the great gate of the six consciousnesses. The vajra guards the place where the mind abides, knowing the place where the mind abides. In the place where the mind abides, the mind does not abide.
If the mind does not abide, the mind then does not abide;
Not abiding in evil and realms, then not grasping;
Departing from grasping, the mind then has no seeking;
If the mind has no seeking, the mind then has no abiding;
If there is no place of abiding, it is called truly abiding mind.
Good sons!
The mind of sentient beings creates various afflictions, all arising from the non-abiding of the mind-spirit.
If the mind abides, then there are no afflictions;
If there are no afflictions, then that is bodhi.
Bodhisattva Akasagarbha addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
Sentient beings create various afflictions because their minds do not abide. From what power do they arise and grasp?
May the Buddha, out of compassion, proclaim it for the multitude.
The Buddha said:
All sentient beings create various conditions, possessing two kinds of nature and power.
What are the two?
First, arising from external objects, this is the power of conditioned nature;
Second, arising from one's own mind without relying on objects, this is the power of nature.
Good man!
If one causes sentient beings not to give rise to the two natures, then there will be no afflictions and no enlightenment.
If there are no afflictions and no enlightenment, entering the true reality, this is true enlightenment.
You bodhisattvas, if you are to transform sentient beings, you should cause their minds to abide.
Bodhisattva Akasagarbha addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
Transforming and liberating sentient beings, causing their minds to abide, abiding in what place can one attain enlightenment?
The Buddha told Bodhisattva Akasagarbha:
Excellent, excellent!
Good man!
You are able to ask about the meaning of mind in this way. This is a great bodhisattva mahÄsattva of inconceivable [virtue].
You should listen attentively, and I will explain it for you.
Good sons!
If one transforms sentient beings and causes their minds to abide, abiding is neither within nor without, nor in between;
The Dharma of the Buddhas' vehicle is also neither within nor without, nor in between;
Abiding in the mind of one thought in a place of no abiding, one thus attains bodhi.
If one attains bodhi, there is also no bodhi to be attained. This is called suchness.
Why is it so?
Afflictions arise in vain, because they are vain and empty;
All dharmas do not arise by themselves, because dharmas are also empty;
This mind only has the name of emptiness, and the mind is also ungraspable, because the mind is also empty.
Good sons! If one knows the mind is empty, one should not falsely see all things in a single empty mind;
If one sees all things, it is then called the defilement of the mind.ğŸ”½Good sons!
If the mind is free from defilements, it is called the exhaustion of afflictions, and the eye, form, and mind realms are always pure and empty.
Bodhisattva Akasagarbha said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!

If all dharmas are thus, all sentient beings should be able to enter one buddha-realm with one body, one mind, and one world, and one buddha-realm should be able to enter all buddha-dharma realms filling the entire space.
The Buddha told Bodhisattva Akasagarbha:
Good man!
It is so, it is so.

All worlds enter one world, and in each world there is a lotus seat, and in each lotus there is a seat for each tathagata. The body of each tathagata fills all worlds, manifesting that all worlds are completely empty.
The buddhas adorn all worlds, and each bodhisattva body fills all worlds.

They have great spiritual powers, and can place all worlds in a single pore, and all worlds enter the body of a single sentient being. The number of each sentient being's body and each world is one Buddha. Each Buddha's enlightenment site is one enlightenment tree. Under each enlightenment tree is a single Buddha seat, and a single Buddha's body fills all worlds. Each Buddha's wondrous voice also fills all worlds. All worlds, according to what is appropriate, are all heard and understood and are all delighted.
The practitioners know that the Dharma is in their own bodies, and should not seek the Buddha's body elsewhere in all worlds. They should seek the Buddha's body in a single mind and a single world.
In a single body, they can give rise to all bodies, and in all bodies, they can give rise to a single body.
Why is this?
Because a single body is a single Buddha's body.

The bodies of all sentient beings, the bodies of sentient beings and the bodies of Buddhas are all born from one mind. If the mind is good, all dharmas are completely good. If the mind is evil, all dharmas are completely evil. If one creates evil karma, one will be born in the body of an evil sentient being. If one creates good karma, one will be born in the bodies of devas and humans. If one is free from the notion of one mind within one mind, there is nothing to be attained in the characteristics of the mind. Moreover, being free from the realm of the empty mind, one is able to give rise to the body of a Buddha on the ground of non-grasping.
Within the body of a Buddha, there is only one body, not two, because of the one Buddha-nature.
Within the one Buddha-nature, there is only the one mind-nature. Outside of the one mind, there is nothing else to seek. If one seeks elsewhere, it is a perversion.
Why is it so?
All mental dharmas are not due to external requests. The place of external requests is called other. If one seeks elsewhere, it is called false.
Bodhisattva Ä€kÄÅ›agarbha addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
Those who attain Buddhahood in a single thought have Buddha-nature in all thoughts, and all sentient beings have Buddha-nature.
If each one can concentrate their body and mind, they will attain Buddhahood. Apart from this, there is no other place to seek Buddhahood.
The Buddha told Bodhisattva Akasagarbha:
Good man!ğŸ”½It is just as you have said.
All sentient beings have Buddha-nature.
All Buddhas and Tathagatas use the Dharma of the one mind to cause all sentient beings and all their minds to seek the Buddha Dharma and attain the Buddha's body in a single thought.
Bodhisattva Akasagarbha said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
If all sentient beings have Buddha-nature and seek to attain Buddhahood within Buddha-nature, all sentient beings have minds and also have Buddha-nature, which can be attained and seen.
The Buddha told Bodhisattva Akasagarbha:
Good sons!
Entering the marvelous reality of the Buddha's true nature, it cannot be attained, nor is it unattainable; it cannot be seen, nor is it unseen.
Why is this?
If bodhisattvas say the Buddha-nature exists, it is called slandering the Buddha;
if they say the Buddha-nature does not exist, it is also slandering the Buddha;ğŸ”½if they say the Buddha-nature both exists and does not exist, it is also slandering the Buddha;
if they say the Buddha-nature is neither existent nor nonexistent, it is also slandering the Buddha.
Why is this?
The Buddha-nature of bodhisattvas and sentient beings is not existent like empty space, and not nonexistent like a rabbit's horns;
Because rabbit horns do not exist, empty space is permanent.
It does not have the characteristics of substance, nor does it have the characteristics of emptiness, being apart from all forms and appearances, and therefore without attachment.
It does not abide in the place of birth, and therefore is not defiled; it does not abide in the place of cessation, and therefore is not cut off.
The marvelous characteristics of the Buddha-nature of sentient beings are like this. Saying the Buddha-nature exists is an additionist slander;
To say that buddha-nature does not exist is the slander of deprecation;ğŸ”½To say that buddha-nature is neither existent nor non-existent is the slander of frivolous discourse;
To say that buddha-nature is both existent and non-existent is the slander of contradiction.
Bodhisattva Ä€kÄÅ›agarbha addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
If the buddha-nature of sentient beings is wondrous like this, free from all realms and unstained, just like the nature of space is always pure,
Why do sentient beings create various afflictions?
If they create afflictions, then the mind is defiled.
From where does this defilement of the mind arise?

I only pray that the World-Honored One will proclaim it for the multitude, enabling all sentient beings to hear and know it, enabling all sentient beings to destroy their afflictions, remove the defilements of the mind, and forever part from the entanglements of hindrances.
The Buddha then smiled with joy, using his left palm to rub the bodhisattva's head, emitting a great radiance that universally illuminated everything.
At that time, the great assembly and all sentient beings all greatly rejoiced and leaped for joy.
The Buddha said:
Bodhisattvas ask questions for the sake of sentient beings like this. This is called a correct question, which delivers sentient beings.
If one asks questions for others, this is called a deviant question, which destroys sentient beings.
Bodhisattvas!

You are able to ask correctly, which delivers sentient beings. You and all sentient beings should single-mindedly contemplate and listen attentively, eliminating scattered thoughts and worldly concerns, and sit with a firm mind.
I will proclaim it for you. If you hear the teaching, all sentient beings who commit the ten evil deeds will attain liberation.
Bodhisattva Akasagarbha addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
Our great assembly and all sentient beings are single-minded without any scattered thoughts. We only wish that the World-Honored One will proclaim it for the assembly.
The Buddha told the assembly of bodhisattvas:

All afflictions arise from delusion, all delusions arise from false thoughts, all false thoughts arise from the existence of self, all existence of self arises from the absence of basis, and all absence of basis is itself non-abiding.
Non-abiding and no basis are non-existent;
existence is defilement, non-existence is purity.
In that pure place, it is the perfection of permanence, the perfection of bliss, the perfection of self, and the perfection of purity.
If one has this view, it is called right view;
if one has other views, it is called wrong view.
One who has this view has wisdom;
one who has other views lacks wisdom.
One who has wisdom is liberated through skillful means;
one who lacks wisdom is bound by skillful means.
Bodhisattva Ä€kÄÅ›agarbha addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

In that pure place, if there are sentient beings who always give rise to the thought of permanence, always give rise to the thought of bliss, always give rise to the thought of self, and always give rise to the thought of purity, then they have wisdom and are not deluded.
The Buddha said:
Bodhisattva!
If there are sentient beings who have such thoughts, they are called right thoughts. Such people have right views and have wisdom.
Why is this?

The Dharma body of the TathÄgata is the perfection of permanence, the perfection of bliss, the perfection of self, and the perfection of purity. The Buddha's Dharma body is pure. Those who see it in this way are true disciples of the Buddha, born from the right Dharma, born from the Dharma, born from the Buddha's mouth, and attain the Buddha's four reliances. Although they are called ordinary beings, they are bodhisattvas who rely on the four reliances.
Good man!

After my extinction, if there are people who, for five hundred years, or one thousand years, or one thousand five hundred years after, are able to receive and uphold this sÅ«tra, recite it as taught, and practice accordingly, and in the place of permanence, bliss, self, and purity, have right views with faith, and further teach this Dharma to a single sentient being, they will be called bodhisattvas. Although they are called ordinary beings, they will receive offerings and be lay practitioners.
Bodhisattva Ä€kÄÅ›agarbha addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

Those who have left the household life shave their beards and hair, don the Dharma robes, uphold the precepts, and are unstained by worldly affairs. This is called leaving the household life and receiving offerings.
The TathÄgata now says that ordinary beings who have left the household life receive offerings, but I do not understand the meaning.
I only wish that the Buddha, out of compassion, will proclaim it for me.
The Buddha told Bodhisattva Ä€kÄÅ›agarbha:
Good man!
Shaving the beard and hair means cutting off conceptual thoughts and subduing the notion of a self in the body;
Wearing the Dharma robes, with a sincere mind free from flattery and deceit, wishing to leave worldly affairs;
Upholding the precepts without giving rise to greed, anger, or delusion;
I say that such a person is called one who has left the household life.

Although they are ordinary beings, they are able to subdue their body and mind, not giving rise to arrogance, their minds unstained by worldly affairs, their minds long since free from worldly matters, like indestructible vajra precepts, although they are ordinary beings they are true renunciants.

Moreover, in this teaching of the Mahayana sutras, practicing as taught, believing in the Buddha's words, seeing permanence, bliss, self, and purity, proclaiming it for sentient beings, although they are ordinary beings they are the four types of people who rely on the Dharma, they are practicing bodhisattvas, and can receive offerings, called practitioners.

Attaining wisdom and skillful means, expounding the Mahayana Dharma, such Dharma-nature is all inseparable from the mind, born from the mind, eternally still and one, with one characteristic and no duality, within the one characteristic there is no inside or outside, no middle, because it is free from everything.
If one is apart from all, then there is no arising or ceasing;
That which has no arising or ceasing is precisely true suchness;
True suchness is eternally abiding, the Dharma and Saá¹ƒgha do not cease, and the beings of the three realms are born and cease by themselves.
Good sons!
Therefore, it is said that sentient beings are without self, and the buddhas, the tathÄgatas, are the true self, because they can destroy the flow of birth and death.
You sentient beings!
If you seek the eternally abiding, you should abandon all desires and cultivate the practice of non-arising.
Bodhisattva Ä€kÄÅ›agarbha addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
What karmic activity is called the practice of non-arising?
The Buddha said:
Good sons!
I do not give rise to others, then others do not give rise to me.
Why is it so?ğŸ”½The essence is pure emptiness, neither existent nor nonexistent, and eternally abiding;
All objects are empty and pure, neither nonexistent nor discontinuous.

Bodhisattvas and Buddhas always use the fragrance of one taste and one nature to fumigate the pure nature of the single mind of sentient beings. The wise attain the understanding of emptiness, while the foolish enter into deluded attachment.
Why is this?

Because sentient beings with wisdom are free from delusion. In the nature of awakened existence, they are aware of the arising of ignorance, but do not give rise to non-awakening, which is not empty and indeterminate. They enter the single purity and are forever free from afflictions.
Sentient beings with delusion, because of having delusion, are not aware of ignorance in the nature of awakened existence. They then give rise to non-awakening and create various afflictions.
If there is awakened awareness, then there is no non-awakening;
if there is no non-awakening, then illness does not arise;
if illness does not arise, then there is no awakened existence.
If there is no awakened existence and no non-awakening, then there is no deluded mind.
Why is this?
Because there are two intentions in a single doubting mind.
If there is no doubting mind, then illness does not arise;
if there is a place of arising, then one enters an empty house.
The one nature of true emptiness is conditioned by no characteristics, encountering circumstances arising like empty illusions.
Bodhisattvas cause sentient beings to sever doubts, to be their own teachers, not following the mind, leaving all desires without negligence.

If mindfulness arises, it should be severed. The previous moment and subsequent moments of thought are not in conflict, thus one accords with principle and does not give rise to ignorance. Since there is no definite awareness and the root is originally unmoving, if thoughts arise, stop the previous arising.
Bodhisattva Ä€kÄÅ›agarbha addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
If the previous thought arises, what Dharma awareness can stop it?
The Buddha said:
Bodhisattvas cause practitioners to always contemplate the dwelling place of the mind, knowing that the dwelling place of the mind is precisely not dwelling in the mind.
Because of this awareness, awareness stops it. If thoughts do not arise, there is neither stopping nor contemplation.

If there is a place of arising, abiding in empty space, in the one nature of emptiness, both defilement and purity cease, the intrinsically pure nature is neither grasped nor abandoned, recollection also does not arise, unborn and unconditioned, where the mind goes is extinguished, and the path of speech is cut off.
One Buddha-nature awareness is without any other awareness. The wondrous nature always exists, just like empty space, not attached to anything.
If a bodhisattva practices this practice, it is like holding a staff to strike empty space, not attached while attached. This is called practicing the Dharma.

If there is a place of attachment, then enter the outside and roam the pure ground, single-mindedly without duality, enter the correct nature of concentration, contemplate the one true reality, and repent.

At that time, there was an icchantika named Much Desire in the assembly. Since ancient times, he had done many evil deeds, exclusively practicing the ten evils, being dragged by the four snakes of hatred, jealousy, and resentment, and having his mind-root gnawed by the two mice of delusion and imagination.
It is like a person hanging from a rope on a tree, with four snakes below spitting venom towards them, and two rats gnawing at the rope trying to cut it.
If the mind is extinguished, then the three karmas are purified;
If the mind is not extinguished, then the eyes, forms, and mind all become deluded thoughts, bound by views and about to fall into hell.

At that time, the icchantika, because of the Buddha's teaching, gave rise to a sense of shame and remorse in a single thought, wanting to ask the TathÄgata about the method of repentance, but feeling ashamed and embarrassed he was unable to ask.

The TathÄgata's spiritual powers immediately knew his thoughts, wanting to cause this person to be free from all suffering and distress, and to escape the door of hell, and said to Bodhisattva Ä€kÄÅ›agarbha:

After my nirvÄá¹‡a, if there are icchantikas who commit many evil deeds, destroy the three jewels of the Buddha, slander the true Dharma and commit the five heinous crimes, they will certainly fall into the various hells and not be able to escape for twelve great eons.
You bodhisattvas should give rise to a compassionate mind, causing these sentient beings to confess and repent, and all attain liberation.
Bodhisattva Ä€kÄÅ›agarbha addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
What methods should be used to repent and remove offenses?
May the Buddha, out of compassion, explain this in detail.
The Buddha said:
If bodhisattvas wish to repent, they should contemplate the truth. If they see the truth, all offenses will be eliminated.

After the Buddha spoke these words, in the assembly, hundreds of thousands of myriads of koá¹­Ä«s of all kinds of sentient beings, humans and non-humans, all single-mindedly contemplated the one true reality. Having contemplated and seen it, their karmic offenses were all extinguished, except for the icchantikas who did not see it.
That icchantika, who had much desire, immediately rose from his seat, prostrated with his whole body, and addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

My mind is ignorant. Although I study and contemplate, I do not see the truth. From beginningless time up to the present, I have solely engaged in the ten evil deeds. What expedient means can I use to enable me to see the truth and eliminate my offenses?
The Buddha said to those with much desire:
You icchantikas should all be single-minded. I will explain and expound for you.
Those with much desire!
You sentient beings should contemplate the one Buddha-nature of body and mind. The Dharma body Buddha-nature is one, not two.
If these two can be made into one contemplation, this is called right contemplation, also called the single-aspect right view.
If one sees there to be two, this is called wrong. If one acts with wrong views, then afflictions arise.
If there are no wrong views, afflictions do not arise. If afflictions are severed, this is called pure.
The Buddha said:
You sentient beings should all be single-minded and contemplate the one Buddha-nature. Apart from the Buddha-nature, there is nothing else to be seen.
If there is something seen, it is all false. To create this falsehood is to be upside down.
Many desires!
If the mind is pure, then the dharmas are pure. If the mind is defiled, then the many dharmas are defiled. Defilement is sin, purity is truth. If the mind is free from defilement, sin will not arise.
Many desires said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!

From the past up to today, I have created immeasurable and boundless evil karma, spanning thousands of myriads of kalpas. Today I give rise to the mind, contemplate the true reality of a single Buddha-nature, and all boundless sins are completely eliminated, is that so?
I only wish that the World-Honored Buddha would explain it for me, so that I can be single-minded without doubt.
The Buddha said:
Many desires!
If one contemplates true reality, all sins are eliminated.
Why is it so?
Many desires!
The defiled mind of the past and the pure mind of today are one mind, without two, and there is no other mind;
Today's mind is pure, and the mind of the past was also pure. Therefore, you should know that from countless eons ago, all offenses have been extinguished.
It is like a dusty mirror for a thousand years, wiped with a cloth once, and the mirror becomes bright, with all the dust gone, leaving no trace.
It is also like a dark room for a thousand years, with a torch lit, all the darkness gone.
You sentient beings!
You should always single-mindedly contemplate the one true reality, practice all dharmas within all dharmas, and depart from all dharmas in the world.
Why is it so?
Many desires!

The moving and unmoving dharmas in the world all decay. If the dharma decays, practice is also impermanent. If practice is impermanent, then the dharma arises and ceases. Departing from the dharma of arising and ceasing is called true reality.
Many desires!

It is like a potter making various pottery vessels, according to his wishes the vessels are not fixed. The characteristics and names of the vessels all arise and cease, only the nature of clay, one nature is permanent. The other forms all arise and cease. The body of arising and ceasing does not arise by itself. If it does not arise by itself, then it does not exist.
Dveá¹£avajrÄ!
The Buddha-nature is like clay, the nature of sentient beings is like a vessel, this is a dharma of arising and ceasing.
If one leaves all karmic actions, then one is the Buddha-body. Contemplating the body of one Buddha, there are no other karmic actions.
Dveá¹£avajrÄ said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
I contemplate the true reality, all offenses have already ceased. What karmic actions are created to give rise to the dharma-body?
The Buddha told Dveá¹£avajrÄ:
If one contemplates the true reality, all illnesses do not arise and offenses and defilements both cease. The mind is like vajra, ultimately indestructible;
One is able to uphold the precepts well, the mind is like empty space, pure inside and out;
Skillfully entering the samadhi of meditation, the mind is like wind and fire, and all activities are scattered;
Skillfully relying on wisdom, it is called liberation, and because of liberation, one is able to know and see.
Kama!
If you are able to practice this, you will attain the five parts of the Dharma body.
Kama said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
What are the causes and effects of the five parts of the Dharma body?
The Buddha said:
Kama!
The Buddha-nature is the constant cause, and the Dharma body is the constant effect.
Why is it so?

The cause is the Buddha-nature of the mind, and the effect is attained through conditions. Apart from cause and effect, there are no causes and effects. If there are no causes and effects, this is the true body of the Buddha.
Kama!

In the pure land of the mind, one should abide in tranquility and observe true mindfulness. Within this mindfulness, the pure land is born. One can teach the Dharma as it is for sentient beings, enter the true emptiness of the mind and speak of leaving all agitation. The three consciousnesses and one nature are indestructible like vajra.

At that time, there was another bodhisattva in the assembly named Non-Action, who immediately rose from his seat, bared his right shoulder, touched his right knee to the ground, joined his palms towards the Buddha, and said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
If after the Buddha's extinction, in five hundred years, a thousand years, or a thousand five hundred years, if I expound the Dharma for sentient beings, what Dharma should I expound?
I only wish that the Buddha, out of compassion, would proclaim it for me, so that I may be free from doubt.
The Buddha told the bodhisattva Non-Action:
Good man!

If after a thousand five hundred years, you expound the Dharma for sentient beings, expound the essence but not the characteristics, expound the meaning but not the words, such an expounder is a true expounder of the Dharma.
If you expound the words and characteristics, moving the mouth and mind, it is all slander.
Good man!
If you expound the Dharma in the presence of all sentient beings, you should expound it according to the characteristics of suchness and equality.
Why is it so?

At that time, all sentient beings had the same illness, the same mind, the same buddha-nature, and the same equality of all dharmas. Therefore, if one speaks of high and low within this, it is called a deviant teaching, and one's mouth will be broken and one's tongue will be split.
Why is it so?
The mental defilements of all sentient beings are the same defilement, and the mental purity of all sentient beings is the same purity.
Why is it so?
When the minds of all sentient beings are pure, they are the same in the purity of the ten wholesome dharmas;
when the minds of all sentient beings are defiled, they are the same in the defilement of the ten unwholesome dharmas.
If sentient beings are sick, they have the same illness. Sentient beings need medicine, and they should need the same medicine. If one speaks of many dharmas, it is called upside-down.
Why is it so?

It is because of falsely discriminating between wholesome and unwholesome dharmas and destroying all dharmas, and because of following the basis of the teachings and cutting off the path of the Buddha.
If bodhisattvas are going to speak the Dharma, they should speak in accordance with the characteristics of suchness.
The bodhisattva of no practice said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
How is it that the characteristics of suchness are spoken of?
The Buddha told the bodhisattva of no activity:
Good man!

Speaking of the one essence true Dharma is speaking of suchness, speaking of straightforward mind is speaking of suchness, speaking without biased attachment is speaking of suchness, speaking without discrimination is speaking of suchness, speaking of abiding in a single pure place of mind is speaking of suchness, speaking of all inexpressible teachings is speaking of suchness.
At that time, the bodhisattva of no activity, wishing to cause the entire great assembly and all beings to fully understand, again addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
How is it that speaking of the inexpressible is speaking of suchness?
The Buddha told the bodhisattva of no activity:
Good man!
Speaking of the self-characteristics of all dharmas being empty is inexpressible;ğŸ”½Speaking of all taught dharmas being without characteristics is inexpressible;
Speaking of all dharmas being without action is inexpressible.
Good man!
If it is explained like this, it cannot be said to be explaining suchness.
The bodhisattva No-action said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
If the Dharma is explained like this, how can one explain the straight mind in detail?
The Buddha told the bodhisattva No-action:
Good man!

The straight mind is to directly believe in the meaning of the TathÄgata with the mind, and explain without using one's own mind to explain. As for being complete, it means being complete with the meaning of the ten wholesome deeds, the meaning of the four truths, the meaning of the twelve links of dependent arising, the meaning of the six perfections, and the meaning of the three gates of liberation. Being complete with such dharmas, in a single mind, on the ground of a single buddha-nature, is explained as being equal and pure. This is called complete explanation, which is the explanation of suchness.
Why is it so?
It is because all dharmas are together as one.
The bodhisattvas equalize the pure Dharma, just as the great ocean has a single taste. Various precious treasures are obtained by seekers according to their minds.
It is like a single divine elixir, various medicinal herbs combined to form it, curing all illnesses, those who take it are each cured.
One pure Dharma, one pure mind, one Buddha-nature, one pure nature and Dharma are also like this, equal to all dharmas, thus speaking is pure speaking.
If spoken separately, it is impure speaking.
Why is it so?

All sentient beings have Buddha-nature, none lack Buddha-nature, but there are far and near in awakening, none lack the Dharma body. If the faculties are determined, for those of the Lesser Vehicle, teach the Dharma of the Lesser Vehicle, for icchantikas, teach the Dharma of icchantikas.

If spoken like this, it is called not speaking the Dharma of the Buddha Way, it is cutting off the Buddha-nature, it is extinguishing the Buddha's body. The one who speaks the Dharma will for a hundred thousand myriad kalpas fall into the hells, even if the Buddha appears in the world, he will not be able to escape.

Even if they escape, if they are reborn among humans, they will be born in borderlands or low-caste families without the Three Jewels. Their lips will be missing and they will be without tongues, receiving such retribution.
Why is this?

The nature of bodhisattvas and sentient beings is the nature of dharmas. The nature of dharmas is always pure and endowed with all the true characteristics and merits. From the beginning, there is nothing to attain or lose, no arising or perishing. The nature is always true, also without falsehood or afflictions, also without nirvÄá¹‡a or increase or decrease, ultimately pure, and the purity of one nature is precisely the pure nature of bodhi.

The nature of bodhi and the nature of one are without duality, equal and pure, with the path of language cut off, just like space. The inner and outer are pure, this is the one purity, also not abiding within or without, also not abiding in between, without words or speech. How can one discriminate between illness and medicine within this?
If there is no discrimination, this is non-discriminating cognition.
Good sons!
Apart from the one mind, the one purity, and the one buddha-nature, there is no buddha to be sought, no Dharma to be expounded, and no Sangha to be attained.
Why is this?
Because the Buddha is the Dharma, the Dharma is the Sangha, and the Sangha is the unconditioned. The unconditioned is the buddha-nature, and the buddha-nature is the Dharma body.

Therefore, I say that this sÅ«tra speaks only of one sentient being's body, one mind, one purity, one buddha-nature, one buddha's place of enlightenment, and one bodhi tree, filling all worlds and entering the bodies of all sentient beings.
Good man!

All buddhas are born from this sÅ«tra, all dharmas are born from this sÅ«tra, and all the Sangha are seen in this sÅ«tra. One who upholds this sÅ«tra is said to uphold the Three Jewels. One who recollects this sÅ«tra is said to recollect the Three Jewels. One who makes offerings to this sÅ«tra is said to make offerings to the Three Jewels.
Bodhisattva of No-action said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
How does one recollect the Three Jewels?
What kind of blessings does one obtain by recollecting the Three Jewels?
The Buddha told the bodhisattva of no activity:
Good man!
If one recollects the Three Jewels as being like empty space, the blessings are immeasurable and inconceivable.

If one recollects the Three Jewels as abiding in empty space, and in one's mind does not see the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha, then one does not see all dharmas. Not seeing all dharmas, one has no doubts about the Dharma. In a pure place, one recollects the one true characteristic, the Three Jewels of one essence. This is recollecting the Three Jewels.
The bodhisattva of no activity said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!

With a single mind, one correctly recollects the Three Jewels. In the midst of afflictions, one's own mind does not arise, and in the face of conditions, it does not arise. As for all wholesome dharmas, it is also like this.

Abiding in a single pure mind, relying on a single buddha-nature, neither moving nor not moving, not for the sake of the essence of dharmas, saving sentient beings as if they were one's own body, transforming all sentient beings as if transforming a single body, loving all sentient beings as if guarding one's own eyes - is this the practice of a bodhisattva or not the practice of a bodhisattva?
I only wish that the World-Honored Buddha would proclaim it for me.
The Buddha told the bodhisattva of no-action:
This is the practice of a bodhisattva.
If transforming sentient beings, one should make sentient beings uphold the mind but not uphold speech, uphold practice but not uphold the Dharma;
If expounding the Dharma, expound the text but not the characters, expound the meaning but not the text.
Why is this?
Because buddha-nature is the meaning.
Why is this?
Because it is apart from the characteristics of text.
If grasping at the characteristics of text, this is false; if abandoning buddha-nature, this is losing the basis.
Good man!

If one loses the Buddha-nature and seeks the Buddha, it is like treating a person's illness in a shadow, like seeking fire by rubbing ice together, like a bird without wings intending to fly high, one will never attain the Dharma.
Good sons!

In this sutra, regulate the mind to grasp the meaning, do not follow the text to grasp the principle. If one does not grasp the principle, it is called false. One also cannot grasp the empty characteristics on the principle to transform sentient beings, which is called the empty view of icchantikas.

Only make sentient beings in one mind, in the Buddha-nature, observe the real existence, this real existence characteristic is not in existence, nor is it in non-existence. Observing this wondrous existence as the true characteristic, one should immediately abide in the mind, rely on this characteristic place;
If one abides in the characteristic place, it is called pure;
In this pure place, abiding is without basis, abiding is precisely movement.
Therefore, the buddhas, the tathÄgatas, establish all dharmas from the place of no basis.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
At that time, the Bodhisattva of No-action, wanting to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
The Great Sage, the Great Buddha, the Honored One, wanting to enter nirvana and tranquility, in order to save sentient beings,
Expounded the sutra of the true one vehicle.
I abide in the ground of compassion, out of pity for sentient beings, in the definitive meanings, I ask the Buddha about the mind of the one vehicle.
The Dharma spoken by the Tathagata is all apart from the world, entering the true to speak of Buddha-nature, all dharmas are pure.
Apart from words and apart from characteristics, also not in between or outside, speaking is precisely unspeakable,
Therefore it is called speaking suchness.
Therefore, the Dharma of equality abides in the one nature, the one nature of the pure Dharma, originally neither arises nor ceases.
In emptiness and non-emptiness, the wondrous nature is always without substance, liberation and non-liberation, originally pure and unstained.
The various defilements are originally unattached, false attachment is like mud stains, this mud stains itself,
the wondrous nature is always pure.
Purity is nothing to be purified, defilement is also nothing to be defiled, the nature of mud is precisely defilement, the nature of defilement is originally empty.
The nature of defilement is like a mad flower, falling from a tree and returning to its original state, the nature of the tree has no arising or ceasing, the mad flower comes and goes by itself.
The buddha-nature is originally unborn, apart from the place of arising and ceasing, there is no movement or stillness,
the nature is always so by itself.
One by one, not one by one, is not called indescribable, and is also apart from all views, the place of non-seeing can be seen.
Because of permanence, bliss, self, and purity, seeing is precisely bodhi, the wondrous enlightened nature of bodhi, unmoving and nothing to be enlightened to.
This is precisely the body of sentient beings, one mind, one buddha-nature, one buddha, one place of practice,
A great bodhi tree, able to fill the realm of space, universally entering the bodies of sentient beings.
Within the true Three Jewels, there is only one, not two, not dwelling in a place with form and substance,
Also not dwelling at the edge of emptiness, entering into the abode of false existence, ultimately empty and quiescent.
Originally without a fundamental place, establishing all dharmas, teaching and transforming all sentient beings,
Causing them to enter the tathÄgatagarbha.
At that time, the Buddha saw that Bodhisattva of No-action had finished speaking the verse, and then used his spiritual power to emit a great light that universally illuminated the trichiliocosm.
Within that light, the pure lands of the ten directions appeared. All those lands were completely pure and perfect, with all kinds of gardens, forests, and ponds.

In the water of the pond there were five-colored lotus flowers with seats, and on each of the flowers there was a large city. In each of the large cities there was a pure great crystal jewel, and in each of the large crystal jewels there was a TathÄgata's seat, with one thousand two hundred and fifty people together.

The Buddhas all spoke the Dharma of the One Vehicle for the great assembly, causing all sentient beings to abide in the mind that does not move in one body, one Buddha, one nature, and one pure place, not relying on various objects and not entering various wisdoms, the mind being like empty space and not tainted by anything, the mind being like a vajra and not destroying the precepts, the mind being like the ocean and always flowing with wisdom, all attaining liberation, the wisdom and vision of liberation, and the five-part Dharma body.

At that time, the bodhisattva of no activity and the great assembly of all sentient beings, having seen this, greatly rejoiced in their minds and all abided in the one-pointed mind that does not rely on anything and enters the pure place.
The Buddha then withdrew his light and said to the great assembly:
All practitioners!
When I wish to enter nirvana, the time has come.

After my extinction, in the world of the five turbidities and evils, those who practice according to this sutra, contemplate the one body and mind, do not dwell in evil, do not depart from bodhi, will surely attain liberation and the path of the One Vehicle.
The Buddha told the bodhisattva of no practice:
After my extinction, in the world of the five turbidities and evils, those who see this sutra and hear its meaning will be like those who meet the Buddha.

After my extinction, if there is a person who can uphold, recite, and practice according to this sutra, whose mind is unmoved, who is not touched by the dusts and transcends the traces of dust, and who further causes sentient beings to uphold and recite this sutra, and explains its meaning and teaches it, although this person is an ordinary person, he is a bodhisattva like the lion's roar.

At that time, there was another bodhisattva in the assembly named Dharma King. He immediately rose from his seat, circumambulated the Buddha three times, and then stood to one side. He prostrated with his five limbs and addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

After the Tathagata's nirvana, in the five turbidities and evil world of Jambudvipa, I will teach and transform sentient beings, expounding this excellent medicine to cure all illnesses and bring about complete healing;
I will also use the adamantine wisdom sword of this sutra to cut through the ignorance in the minds of all sentient beings;
I will also use the pure Dharma staff of this sutra to whip away the defilements of the three poisons in the minds of sentient beings;
I will also use the great wise warrior of this sutra to liberate sentient beings from the bonds of the ten entanglements;
I will also use the great wisdom Dharma boat of this sutra to ferry sentient beings across to the other shore;

I will also use the Dharma of the single pure nature of this sutra to enable all sentient beings to attain a single body, a single mind, a single Buddha, a single nature, and a single purity, to definitely enter the One Vehicle, and to definitely escape from the hells.
World-Honored One!
If I am unable to save sentient beings, and sentient beings enter the hells, it would be my downfall as a Buddha.
I only pray that the World-Honored One!

Entrust this Buddha-Dharma to me, and further explain it, widely liberating sentient beings, enabling sentient beings to understand much through hearing little and know much through seeing little, not seeking many words to attain the meaning of the teachings, and definitely attaining liberation through a few teachings without any doubts.
I pray that the Buddha, out of compassion, will proclaim it for me.
The Buddha said to the great assembly:

This Dharma King Bodhisattva has already made offerings to Buddhas for hundreds of thousands of myriads of koá¹­is of kalpas, and is well-versed in skillful means to save and liberate sentient beings. This bodhisattva can use the constant wind of one flavor to connect and sustain the lives of sentient beings.
You sentient beings and those in the future!

If one receives and upholds the names of these bodhisattvas, and further causes the great good and wise advisors to turn and read this sutra and extensively explain its meaning, then all illnesses will be completely cured, and no evil beasts or spirits will be able to approach.
Bodhisattvas!

You have such benefits for sentient beings. I entrust this sutra to you, and I will also explain the Dharma for saving and liberating sentient beings for you. With little hearing, you will understand much, with little seeing, you will know much. Do not seek many words to grasp the meaning of the teachings.
You bodhisattvas should all listen single-mindedly, and I will proclaim it for you.
All sentient beings have one mind, one Buddha, and one nature. All afflictions arise from one mind, all arising from the two conditions of objects and cognition.
Why is this so?

Because the power of the two natures of conditioned nature and inherent nature arises, and the power of the two natures arises from the one thought of the deluded mind. This deluded mind has no basis.
When there is a single thought of movement, afflictions arise. One should contemplate this thought and know the deluded mind.
The deluded mind has no root. Without a root, there is no abiding. If one knows non-abiding, then one awakens to the arising of the mind.

Due to the pure mind of original enlightenment being without thought, if the mind is without thought, the mind is then unmoving. If the mind is unmoving, there is also no abiding mind. This is called purity.
The pure empty mind, whose nature is pure, is without purity that can be realized, and is apart from all purities, thus it is said to be pure.

In the pure mind, the bodhisattva has no action, no arising, no defilement, no purity, no increase, and no decrease. Ultimately unstained, not abiding in one place, apart from names and numbers, always thus and not thus. Like a vajra, its single nature is indestructible. Like space, it accommodates everything. Like a lotus, it is unstained by the waters of desire. If one practices this conduct, one will definitely be liberated, transcending the flow of birth and death and escaping the sufferings of hell.
This one mind dharma of the bodhisattva is called repentance and liberation, because it sees the true essence;
Second, the liberation of Dharma practice, because it abides in one place;
Third, the liberation of no practice, because it is without attachment.
These three liberations all arise from one mind, because all sentient beings have no two minds, and because all sentient beings are of one vehicle.
The Buddha said to Dharma King Bodhisattva:
Good man!
If one can know one dharma, then one should know all dharmas. If one does not know one dharma, then one does not know all dharmas.
Why is this?
Because all dharmas are not apart from the one characteristic.
Bodhisattvas who hear of this one are of little learning, but if there is no dharma that is not known, this is called extensive understanding.
Why is this?
Because the nature of all dharmas returns to the one purity.
Seeing this one is seeing the body of all Buddhas.
Why is this?
The body of all Buddhas arises from the one pure place. The one pure ground is the body of all Buddhas, the site of enlightenment of all Buddhas, and the bodhi tree of all Buddhas.
Good man!
In this Dharma, one cuts off all afflictions, just as when felling a tree, one cuts the root and not the branches and leaves.
Why is it so?
It is like a person who is poisoned by an arrow and suffers pain in the body. One should immediately pull out the arrow and the pain will be relieved;
if the arrow is not pulled out, the pain will not be relieved.
One waits to ask what kind of bird's feathers the arrow has,
and further asks in which mountain the bamboo came from,
and further asks who shot the arrow.
The person's pain and life will be over, and pulling out the arrow will be of no benefit in the end.
Good man!
If the mind is defiled, one should immediately purify the mind;
if the mind is in purity, it is then called pure.
All explanations of purity are free from all grasping and can enter non-grasping.
Why is it so?
Because there is no basis and no dwelling place, and one always delights in the pure self;
because there is no basis and no dwelling, true suchness is truly not apart from all, because it is originally apart from separation.
The nature is not apart from the place of the Way, abiding in non-abiding, therefore it is one with the mind, without difference or commonality;
It is not in the place of permanence, because it is originally unbroken;
It does not move or abide, because its nature is always one. One is also not one, because it is apart from names and numbers.
Good sons!

The six winds do not move the great tree, which is always at peace. The single nature is like vajra, and the two views do not arise. Existence and non-existence do not abide in the wonderful permanence and emptiness. The sword of wisdom, which is unborn, cuts off all afflictions. The unobstructed understanding of emptiness subdues one's own mind. The demon king is not born, and the enemy does not arise.
Good sons!

Those who seek the true essence in this Dharma are like planting one seed and not planting branches and leaves. They only nurture the roots. If they can grow, flowers and fruits will naturally appear.
This little Dharma of mine is also like this. It is like the fruit of a single amla fruit. By planting this one fruit, one obtains endless fruits.
I say that this Dharma is the foremost of all dharmas, the greatest of all vehicles, the king of all vehicles. Therefore, this sÅ«tra is called the 'King of Dharma';
Moreover, because this sÅ«tra is entrusted to the Bodhisattva King of Dharma, it is called the 'King of Dharma'.
You great assembly, those who uphold this sÅ«tra will be freed from all difficulties. If you uphold it, it is as if you are upholding it everywhere.
Why is it so?
Buddha-nature is always in the mind, always empty and tranquil, the true and pure vajra of inner meditation, the six sense-gateways always like the realm of suchness, in the place of emptiness.
You great assembly, all do not speak. The time is approaching, I am about to enter nirvÄá¹‡a. This sÅ«tra is called the 'PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ of the Adornments of NirvÄá¹‡a, Unimpeded Liberation'.
After the Buddha spoke this,
at that time the great assembly all attained the emptiness of prajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ of nirvÄá¹‡a, and were liberated without obstruction.

At that time, Bodhisattva Dharma King rose from where he had fallen and entered great nirvana in his original place. He attained liberation in emptiness and non-attachment, and with every step he took, he roamed in purity. He joined his palms in respect, bowed to the Buddha, and departed.
